ROBOTICS

AI-driven robotics transforms
industries through smart automation.

Current Level of AI Usage

AI in robotics is high and still rising. Modern robots rely on AI for perception (vision/SLAM), planning (A*/trajectory optimization), and autonomy (reactive, probabilistic, and learning-based control)1 across most major sectors.

Landmark surveys and tutorials document this arc from symbolic planning to probabilistic SLAM and learning-driven autonomy now fielded in hospitals, warehouses, and planetary missions.2

Historical Growth of AI in Robotics

Late 1960s–1970s
First AI Robot Era
Shakey (SRI): Fused computer vision, symbolic STRIPS planning, and action—establishing the template for AI-in-robotics.3
A* Search (1968): Formalized heuristic pathfinding used in robot navigation, from mobile bases to manipulators.4
1980s
Behavior-Based Control
Subsumption Architecture: Introduced robust, layered, reactive control for real-time autonomy in the real world.5
1990s–2000s
Probabilistic Robotics & SLAM
SLAM: Tutorials and proofs showed SLAM is solvable and provided the Bayesian toolkit (EKF/graph-based) that underpins today’s navigation.6
2010s
Deep Perception & Resilient Autonomy
Robust Perception Age: SLAM’s maturation enabled large-scale real deployments.7
2020s
Learning-Based Control & Domain Rollouts
Fielded Autonomy: Hospitals (AMRs), space (Perseverance AutoNav), and autonomous surgery reach preclinical success.8

First Known AI Application

Shakey the Robot (1966–1972):
  • Widely recognized as the first mobile system to perceive, plan, and act using integrated AI methods.3
  • Combined computer vision, symbolic planning (STRIPS), and action execution.
  • Set the template for all future AI-driven robotics, influencing both academic research and real-world deployments.
  • Demonstrated autonomous navigation, obstacle avoidance, and task completion in a structured environment.

Notable Applications of AI in Robotics

Industrial & Human-Robot Collaboration

Safety-aware collaboration and intention-sensitive interfaces in factories.9

Intralogistics / Warehouses (AMRs)

Planning, task allocation, and fleet control for AMRs.10
Latest advances and limits in AMRs.11

Healthcare & Surgery

Autonomous laparoscopic surgery (STAR system).12
Hospital AMRs: benchmarking navigation.13
FDA-cleared surgical robots by autonomy.14

Space Robotics

Mars Perseverance: onboard autonomy (AutoNav, visual odometry, scene understanding).15
Mars Exploration Rovers: long-duration visual odometry.16

Underwater / Marine

AUVs tracking upwelling fronts using onboard perception & decision-making.17

Aerial Drones

Fast autonomous quadrotor flight in GPS-denied settings.18
Online collision-free trajectory generation on point clouds.19

Agriculture

Phenotyping, precision farming, autonomy trends.20
Harvesting, spraying, weeding platforms.21
Core technologies for crop production.22

Construction & Mining

Autonomous excavator system for material loading.23
Automation trends toward fully autonomous mining systems.24

Service & Domestic Robots

Service robots across domains.25
Trust in home service robots.26

Foundational Methods

  • A* Search: Heuristic pathfinding algorithm, foundational for robot navigation and manipulation.4
    Used in mobile robots, manipulators, and autonomous vehicles for efficient route planning.
  • Subsumption Architecture: Layered, reactive control enabling robust real-time autonomy.5
    Allows robots to respond to dynamic environments and unexpected events.
  • SLAM (Simultaneous Localization and Mapping): Bayesian estimation (EKF/graph-based) for reliable localization and mapping in unknown spaces.6
    Core to autonomous navigation in warehouses, hospitals, and planetary missions.
  • T-RO Survey: Comprehensive reviews and tutorials that underpin robust perception and mapping.6

AI Usage Over Time

  • Symbolic era: Robots reasoned with search/planning (STRIPS, A*).4
  • Reactive era: Subsumption enabled robust real-time behavior.5
  • Probabilistic era: SLAM and Bayesian estimation delivered reliable localization/mapping.6
  • Learning-driven era: Robust perception, manipulation, and decision-making now power AMRs, AUVs, drones, construction/mining equipment, and space rovers.8
Conclusion:
AI usage in robotics is high. The peer-reviewed record shows a steady progression from early symbolic AI to probabilistic and learning-based autonomy, with mission-critical deployments (e.g., hospitals, warehouses, Mars) and domain-specific robots (agriculture, construction, mining, underwater, aerial). Multiple independent scholarly sources confirm broad, mature, and expanding AI adoption.1,2,8
